Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: What is the nature of reality? How can we acquire certain knowledge? These are some of the questions that have challenged humans for millennia and underpin ongoing endeavours in areas as diverse as science, justice and the arts. This unit engages students with fundamental philosophical questions through active, guided investigation and critical discussion of 2 key areas of philosophy: epistemology and metaphysics. The emphasis is on philosophical inquiry - 'doing philosophy' - through the formulation and exploration of questions in philosophical exchanges with others. Hence the study and practice of techniques of philosophical reasoning are central to this unit. As students learn to think philosophically, appropriate examples of philosophical viewpoints and arguments, both contemporary and historical, are used to support, stimulate and enhance their thinking about central concepts and problems. At least one of these examples will be from a primary philosophical text using a complete text or an extract. As students investigate central concepts and problems, they will also consider the relationship between philosophical problems and relevant contemporary debates.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentHeader: The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentDescription: Philosophy is an activity as much as it is a body of thought.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentHeader: The nature and methods of philosophy
Elaboration: Students benefit from first understanding the distinctive nature of philosophical thinking before embarking on a deeper study of the questions, problems and ideas that have challenged philosophers for millennia.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentHeader: The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students are introduced to, and practise, a variety of techniques used by philosophers to construct, analyse and evaluate arguments.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentHeader: The nature and methods of philosophy
Elaboration: Students consider what distinguishes philosophical reasoning from other ways of thinking and through so doing, begin to formulate an understanding of the distinctive nature of philosophy.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentHeader: The nature and methods of philosophy
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to analyse the distinctive nature of philosophy and recognise and apply techniques of philosophical reasoning.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and methods of philosophy

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Metaphysics
ContentDescription: Metaphysics is the study of the basic structures and categories of what exists, or of reality.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Metaphysics
Elaboration: It is the attempt to work out a comprehensive account of everything that we know or believe about existence, including all our scientific knowledge.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Metaphysics
ContentDescription: This area of study introduces students to metaphysical problems through a study of questions associated with selected themes.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ContentDescription: The word epistemology derives from 2 Ancient Greek words: episteme meaning ‘knowledge’ and logos meaning ‘what is said about something’.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
Elaboration: In the ancient world, episteme was contrasted with doxa meaning ‘belief’, or something falling short of genuine knowledge.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
Elaboration: This ancient contrast points to one of the basic problems in epistemology: the difference between belief and the certainty associated with knowledge.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
ContentDescription: This area of study introduces students to basic epistemological problems through a study of questions associated with selected themes.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
Elaboration: Students also consider philosophical problems in contemporary debates, including the implications of accepting particular views about knowledge; for example, what are the implications for the authority of science from a position that knowledge, belief and truth are relative to different cultures?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Epistemology
Elaboration: Does considering this implication lead to a revision of the initial position?

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: What are the foundations of our judgments about value? What is the relationship between different types of value? How, if at all, can particular value judgments be defended or criticised?

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: This unit enables students to explore these questions in relation to different categories of value judgment within the realms of morality, political and social philosophy and aesthetics. Students also explore ways in which viewpoints and arguments in value theory can inform and be informed by contemporary debates. They study at least one primary philosophical text, using the complete text or an extract, and develop a range of skills including formulating philosophical questions and developing philosophical perspectives.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ContentDescription: What should I do?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: What is right?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: On what basis can we choose between different courses of action?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: These are ongoing fundamental questions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: In this area of study, students are introduced to key debates in moral philosophy that stretch back thousands of years.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: The laws of our society reflect a position that murder and theft are wrong, but a philosopher is interested in the justifications for these convictions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: Is morality a personal matter or can we give good reasons for holding particular moral beliefs?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: Are there fundamental moral beliefs that should be universally binding, or are they preferences that develop in response to particular cultural contexts?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students are concerned with discovering if there are basic principles and underlying ideas of morality and assessing ethical viewpoints and arguments using philosophical reasoning.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: Philosophical methods may be used to address everyday dilemmas, as well as issues debated in the media and important moral challenges of our times.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ContentDescription: Students explore at least 2 of the themes listed below.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ContentDescription: For at least one of the themes selected, students must study a minimum of one primary text.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
Elaboration: Suggested thinkers are recommended at the end of each section, from which an appropriate primary text or texts can be selected, or an appropriate thinker outside this list could be studied.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Ethics and moral philosophy
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: In addition to discussing ethical and moral value, philosophers consider a range of other types of values, including social, political and aesthetic value.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Often philosophers concern themselves with questions regarding the foundations of particular forms of value.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: They consider whether these various forms of value are grounded in the nature of things or whether they are human creations.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: If they are human creations, students consider whether these forms of value might yet appeal to commonly held or universal standards.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: How these questions are approached may depend upon the type of value considered.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: At other times, philosophers set aside these foundational questions and consider particular questions relating to social, political or aesthetic value.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Is democracy the only justifiable form of government?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: What are the obstacles to freedom?

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: How are conflicts between rights to be resolved?

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: What is the point of art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: This area of study provides students with an introduction to some of these questions and the ways in which philosophers have addressed them.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Students explore how philosophical methods can be brought to bear on a range of questions regarding value.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Students study at least 2 of the 4 value theory themes below.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Appropriate questions outside the list can also be included for study.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: For at least one of the themes selected, students must study at least one primary text.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Suggested thinkers are recommended at the end of each section, from which an appropriate primary text or texts can be selected, or an appropriate thinker outside this list could be studied.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Questions that may be explored in this theme include:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is a right?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the basis of and justification for rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What are human rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: What determines the content and extent of human rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: To what extent are there and should there be constraints on our rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: How are conflicts between rights to be resolved?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: How are rights related to responsibilities?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Do only human beings have rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Do animals have rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Do communities, cultures or environments have rights?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is justice?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the relationship between law and justice?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Is the state justified in punishing criminals?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Suggested thinkers: Mary Wollstonecraft, John Stuart Mill, Karl Marx, Simone Weil, John Rawls, Peter Singer, Robert Nozick, Richard Sylvan (Routley), Mary Midgley, Michael Walzer, Danielle Allen, Deborah Bird Rose.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Questions that may be explored in this theme include:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Is freedom a fundamental human right?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: To what degree is the state justified in limiting individual freedom?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the distinction between positive and negative liberty?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the social contract?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Is democracy the only justifiable form of polity?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the relationship between free markets and free societies?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Suggested thinkers: Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, John Stuart Mill, Robert Nozick, Adam Smith, Isaiah Berlin, Axel Honneth, Richard Rorty.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Questions that may be explored in this theme include:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is beauty?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Is beauty necessary or even desirable in art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What defines the aesthetic? (For example, exploration of such concepts as taste, aesthetic properties, aesthetic experience, aesthetic appreciation and the relationship between these).

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: To what extent does art transcend everyday moral categories?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the purpose and value of art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Is there a legitimate distinction between ‘high’ and ‘low’ art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Is there a distinction to be made between art and craft?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Can an aesthetic judgment be wrong?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Are some aesthetic judgments better or worse than others?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Suggested thinkers: Plato, David Hume, Immanuel Kant, RG Collingwood, Arthur Danto, Elaine Scarry.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Questions that may be explored in this theme include:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the relationship between art and philosophy?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the relationship between the meaning of a work and the intentions of its artist?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the relationship between the meaning of an artwork and its context?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the Intentional Fallacy?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: To what extent is it a fallacy?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: To what extent is a society justified in censoring art?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: How important is originality in the arts?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Should we condemn forgeries or even honest copies?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: In what sense can we speak of meaning in non-representational art (for example, music)?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is a metaphor?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Can we say that a metaphor is ‘true’?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: What is the relationship between a work of art and what it represents?

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: Suggested thinkers: WK Wimsatt and MC.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
Elaboration: Beardsley, Arthur Danto, Susanne Langer, Susan Sontag, Nelson Goodman, Alva Noë.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to analyse selected problems in value theory and evaluate viewpoints and arguments in response to these problems, and discuss philosophical issues in the context of relevant contemporary debates.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Further problems in value theory
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentHeader: Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students critically reflect on their experience of doing philosophy and develop perspectives on the nature, purpose and value of philosophy.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentHeader: Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
Elaboration: Students consider the distinctive nature of philosophical reasoning, how it privileges certain ways of thinking over others and the merits and shortcomings of this.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentHeader: Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
Elaboration: Students also consider what perspectives and voices have traditionally been elevated or excluded in philosophical discourse, such as the voices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples, and the implications this has for our understanding of the nature and purpose of philosophy.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentHeader: Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
Elaboration: Students reflect on the value of philosophy for navigating questions of contemporary living.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentHeader: Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to explain and evaluate the nature, purpose and value of philosophy.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 3 - Philosophy: its nature, purpose and value

ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 3.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: This unit considers the crucial question of what it is for a human to live well. It explores questions of relevance to our own good lives - what is happiness? What role should pleasure and self-discipline, friendship and love play in the good life? - as well questions regarding the good life as it may be understood within the context of our relationships with others beyond our immediate communities. Students consider the implications of adopting particular perspectives, viewpoints and arguments for questions of relevance to contemporary living, such as our relationship with those beyond our immediate communities, non-human animals and the broader natural world.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: Students engage with the set texts to develop perspectives on questions relating to the good life, including questions of relevance to contemporary living. Through critical reflection on ideas, perspectives, viewpoints and arguments, students develop and defend their own philosophical positions.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: In this study, the term 'text' refers to a complete text or extract(s) from a philosophical work.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: Texts for Units 3 and 4 are prescribed annually by the VCAA and referred to in Units 3 and 4 as 'set texts'. The prescribed texts for each unit will be published annually in the VCAA Bulletin.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The good life and the individual
ContentHeader: The good life and the individual
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students consider what a good life is by exploring their own and others’ responses to 4 general questions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The good life and the individual
ContentHeader: The good life and the individual
Elaboration: Students use the concepts, arguments and viewpoints in the set texts as well as their own and others’ examples, to develop perspectives on these 4 questions and questions of relevance to contemporary living.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The good life and the individual
ContentHeader: The good life and the individual
Elaboration: Through critical reflection on these perspectives and their underpinning concepts, viewpoints and arguments, students develop and defend their own philosophical positions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The good life and the individual
ContentHeader: The good life and the individual
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students broaden the scope of their examination of the good life from the individual to the individual’s relationship with others, including the wider community.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
Elaboration: Students use concepts, arguments and viewpoints in the set texts to develop perspectives on general questions relating to the nature of the good life as it is expressed through our relationships with others, and they re-examine their positions on the good life for the individual in light of this.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
Elaboration: Students develop perspectives on the implications of particular viewpoints, arguments and perspectives for questions of relevance to contemporary living with others.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
Elaboration: These questions might consider how we should organise our communities, our relationships with others beyond our immediate communities (including non-human animals and the natural world) and whether we have an obligation to help those beyond our immediate communities.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
Elaboration: Students develop and defend their own philosophical positions as they reflect on the merits and shortcomings of these perspectives and their underpinning concepts, viewpoints and arguments.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to discuss philosophical questions relating to the good life and others.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - The good life and others
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: In recent decades, developments in information and communication technologies have changed the way we share beliefs and acquire and justify knowledge. More than ever, we rely on the testimony of others, in particular, those we judge to be experts. But what is an expert? What qualities must testimony have to be trusted? And, in a world filled with multiple and often contradictory sources, how do we separate good beliefs from poor beliefs?

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: This unit focuses on interpersonal aspects of belief and belief formation, considering what it means to believe well by examining the nature of belief and the grounds for accepting or rejecting beliefs. Across 2 areas of study, students explore what our obligations are in relation to belief; when we should adjust or change our beliefs; and to what extent we should take responsibility for fostering the good beliefs of others and the conditions that make them possible. Through so doing, students are invited to consider the interrelationship between believing well and living well.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: In Area of Study 1, students use concepts, arguments and viewpoints from the set texts to develop perspectives and justified philosophical positions on belief formation and justification in relation to a range of general questions. Students apply their learning from Area of Study 1 to identify and engage with epistemological issues that arise from case studies suggested by selected contexts.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: In this study, the term 'text' refers to a complete text or extract(s) from a philosophical work.

Subject: Philosophy
ContentDescription: Texts for Units 3 and 4 are prescribed annually by the VCAA and referred to in Units 3 and 4 as 'set texts'. The prescribed texts for each unit will be published annually in the VCAA Bulletin.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Foundations of belief
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students explore philosophical questions relating to the interpersonal aspects of belief formation and the interrelationship between believing well and living well.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Foundations of belief
Elaboration: Students use the concepts, arguments and viewpoints from the set texts to develop perspectives on these questions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Foundations of belief
Elaboration: As they reflect on the merits and shortcomings of these perspectives and the underpinning concepts, viewpoints and arguments, they formulate and defend their own philosophical positions.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Foundations of belief
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: An important aspect of the study of philosophical viewpoints and arguments is developing the capacity to identify and respond to relevant matters of practical concern.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: In this area of study, students examine 2 case studies drawn from 2 contexts.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
Elaboration: They examine the case studies in light of the general questions and associated concepts, arguments and viewpoints found in relevant set texts in Area of Study 1.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
Elaboration: The contexts are used to help identify a case study that involves epistemological issues.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
Elaboration: For example, students could explore how social media has been used in election campaigns, which is a case study suggested by one of the following contexts: misinformation, disinformation and echo chambers.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
Elaboration: Students use the concepts, general questions, arguments and viewpoints from Area of Study 1 to illuminate and explore the epistemological issues relating to the case study.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: Two contexts with one case study for each must be selected.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
Elaboration: The contexts for study are:

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: silencing, exclusion and cancelling

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: misinformation, disinformation and echo chambers

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: truth, trust, credibility and expertise.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: On completion of this unit, the student should be able to discuss case studies in light of epistemological issues associated with belief, belief formation and justification.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: To achieve this outcome, the student will draw on key knowledge and key skills outlined in Area of Study 2.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: The examination will be set by a panel appointed by the VCAA.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
Elaboration: All the key knowledge and key skills that underpin the outcomes in Units 3 and 4 are examinable.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: Duration: 2 hours.

Subject: Philosophy
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
ContentDescription: Date: at the end of the year, on a date to be published annually by the VCAA.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Contemporary applications
